comments.body: Maybe add a `-f` in here so it fails properly.
It doesn't, though, because Bash doesn't propagate errors through pipes. You just end up with an empty `PR`. Maybe I should check for that? ðŸ¤”
It does if you `set -o pipefail`, which you have, doesn't it?

Not in a subshell. `-o pipefail` works for pipes in the current script but in my experience (and I tested it for this one) it doesn't in subshells. Or maybe it is that Bash doesn't propagate errors through string interpolation? Not quite sure what the actual issue is, but it does succeed on that statement and sets the variable to an empty string. (I think; now that I say it I did not try to differentiate between empty string and unset.)

```
bash-3.2$ set -euo pipefail
bash-3.2$ echo "hello $(exit 1) world"
hello  world
bash-3.2$ 
```

ðŸ¤”
The more I test this the more confused I get.

So Bash does seem to fil as expected now. I'm pretty sure I tested it about an hour ago and it didn't, but ðŸ¤· . Thinking more about it, though, in this case, I do not want it to fail, as the Slack notification is still useful even if the script does not manage to get the PR number.

Subshells are not pipes.

```
$ ((exit 1) | echo 'hello, world'); echo $?
hello, world
0
$ (set -o pipefail; (exit 1) | echo 'hello, world'); echo $?
hello, world
1
```
That said, I like your fix that just reports anyway. ðŸ™‚

I don't. I keep forgetting about `true` for some reason. Given that it's already merged I don't think this is worth changing, but I'll try to keep it in mind next time.

Also note that the newline is actually discarded by the assignment here:
```
bash-3.2$ a=$(fail || echo "")
bash: fail: command not found
bash-3.2$ b=$(fail || true)
bash: fail: command not found
bash-3.2$ declare -p a
declare -- a=""
bash-3.2$ declare -p b
declare -- b=""
bash-3.2$ 
```

@@ -1,1 +526,530 @@        # This series of pipes extracts the `username:password` part.

comments.body: Is `http.https` intentional?

The git config format lets you have "subsections", for example
```
[branch master]
  remote = ...
[branch temp]
  remote = ...
```
so all the `branch` things have the same structure, but a different name. For the `git config` command, you access them with `section.subsection.attribute`, so `git config branch.master.remote`.

There's an `http` section that uses the URL as the subsection, so the file looks like:
```
[http https://github.com/digital-asset/daml]
  extraheader = Authorization: basic username:password
```
I expected I'd need some sort of escaping to include the URL in the `git config` call, but apparently not, despite the presence of a dot in the URL. ðŸ¤·
ah makes sense, thanks for the explanation!

        else

@@ -1,1 +822,826 @@          }

          if [ "$(is_release)" == "true" ]; then
              # releases matter to everyone

comments.body: This feels a bit off. Shouldnâ€™t we consider this a blocking check and do something like using a special format for the update PR and match on that on every PR?
I'm not sure I understand what you mean here. This will trigger an independent build that reports its status to the branch and thus blocks the PR, exactly as if you'd triggered it through the web UI.
Ah I didnâ€™t know independent builds were considered blocking. Then this seems reasonable :+1:

My understanding is that:
- We have a set number of builds that GH will wait for specifically; however
- All builds reported for the "tip" commit of a PR are part of the PR status;
- Any build reported as anything else than succeeded (i.e. pending or failed) blocks the PR from being merged.

I'll keep an eye on this when we do the next snapshot.

comments.body: Feels a bit weird to be using an `http` call in a signing phase. Any chance you could turn this into an `https` call?

I took a short look at [RFC 3161](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3161.txt) which defines the timestamping protocol and it looks like that has a custom signing mechanism so presumably thatâ€™s why using HTTP is reasonable here.
